skill.name: biopython
skill.description: Comprehensive molecular biology toolkit. Use for sequence manipulation, file parsing (FASTA/GenBank/PDB), phylogenetics, and programmatic NCBI/PubMed access (Bio.Entrez). Best for batch processing, custom bioinformatics pipelines, BLAST automation. For quick lookups use gget; for multi-service integration use bioservices.

security_audit.summary: All 525 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. This is a documentation skill containing markdown files with Biopython code examples. The static analyzer flagged shell commands, file I/O, and network access patterns in documentation examples, but these represent legitimate bioinformatics operations in markdown files, not executable malicious code. No actual security risks present.

content.value_statement: Process DNA, RNA, and protein sequences efficiently. Access NCBI databases programmatically and perform sequence alignments. Automate complex bioinformatics pipelines for research and clinical applications.
actual_capabilities: Read and write biological file formats including FASTA, GenBank, FASTQ, and PDB
Perform pairwise and multiple sequence alignments with BLOSUM and PAM matrices
Access NCBI databases via Bio.Entrez for PubMed, GenBank, and protein searches
Parse and analyze BLAST search results from NCBI or local databases
Parse protein structures from PDB files and calculate molecular properties
Build and manipulate phylogenetic trees from sequence alignments
limitations: Does not include GUI tools or interactive visualization (use PyMOL or similar separately)
Local BLAST requires separate BLAST+ installation and database setup
Does not perform de novo genome assembly or variant calling

best_practices: Always set Entrez.email when accessing NCBI databases to comply with their usage policy
Use iterators like SeqIO.parse() for large files to avoid loading everything into memory
Cache downloaded sequences to avoid redundant network requests and respect rate limits
anti_patterns: Do not hardcode API keys in scripts; use environment variables instead
Do not skip error handling for network operations which can fail due to connectivity issues
Do not process large alignments without checking memory requirements first

faq.question: What file formats does Biopython support?
faq.answer: FASTA, GenBank, FASTQ, EMBL, SwissProt, PDB, mmCIF, and many more alignment formats.

faq.question: How do I access NCBI databases?
faq.answer: Use Bio.Entrez with your email set. Search with esearch, fetch with efetch, and parse results with Entrez.read.

faq.question: Can Biopython run local BLAST searches?
faq.answer: Yes, but requires NCBI BLAST+ installed separately. Use Bio.Blast.Applications for command-line execution.

faq.question: How do I calculate sequence properties?
faq.answer: Use Bio.SeqUtils for GC content, molecular weight, melting temperature, and protein analysis.

faq.question: What is the difference between parse and read?
faq.answer: parse() returns an iterator for multiple records; read() expects exactly one record in the file.

faq.question: How do I handle rate limits with NCBI?
faq.answer: Set Entrez.api_key for 10 requests per second, or use 3 per second without a key. Add delays between requests.
